column67:
Stack Overflow is not meant for posting "opinions"; it's supposed to contain factually correct, verifiable answers to questions. Opinions are explicitly off-topic, and posting opinion-based questions is a good way to get the question closed immediately. Please see https://stackoverflow.com/help/on-topic.

This makes it kind of hard to answer this survey seriously, since it seems to be based on a false premise (that developers seek opinions on Stack Overflow).

Of course there are other forums, but you do single out Stack Overflow. Very confusing.

column8: Actually, StackOverflow does not encourage opinions, it tries to stick to facts. So lists like xml-dev and xsl-list are much better for discussions.

column10: Most of the opinions are not well-researched.
column11: You can usually tell an insightful post very quickly from an ill-informed one by the quality of the language and the logic.

column16:
Unified documentation on Stack Overflow (beta) looks like a positive step in the right direction. However, most design decisions about API have also been made on mailing lists (i.e. outside of forums) and they would also need to be mined to generate a wholistic view of how well an API has been designed.

Besides, Stack Overflow explicitly discourages answers based (only) on opinions. Hence, making the task of mining opinions more difficult.
column17: Will make picking/choosing between multiple APIs which solve the same problem much easier.
column18: The summary may miss key design choices or the meta-information (i.e. maintainability, active development, etc.) of the APIs, thus resulting in https://xkcd.com/927/ for API summaries.
